hints.content:
When we add a number, we jump that distance to the right on the number line.

To show $\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}$, we need to show $\maroonD{2}$ jumps of $\blueD{3}$ units.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 6 with tick marks at 0, 3, and 6. An arrow begins at the 0 tick mark and moves right on the number line, pointing to the labeled tick marks at 3 and 6. Each arrow is labeled plus 3. !

hints.content:
This number line best represents $2\times 3$:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 6 with tick marks at every 1 unit. An arrow begins at the 0 tick mark and moves right on the number line, pointing to the labeled tick marks at 3 and 6. !

choices.content: ![A number line labeled 0 to 3 with tick marks at every 1 unit. An arrow begins at the 0 tick mark and moves right on the number line, pointing to the labeled tick marks at 2 and 3.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/938524eedd8322275e2b50053f01e875870e5d35)

![A number line labeled 0 to 6 with tick marks at every 1 unit. An arrow begins at the 0 tick mark and moves right on the number line, pointing to the labeled tick marks at 3 and 6.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5920f2f80d7e949a496e2a97a3d182579c7dfb71)

![A number line labeled 0 to 5 with tick marks at every 1 unit. An arrow begins at the 0 tick mark and moves right on the number line, pointing to the labeled tick marks at 2 and 5.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/77125352d1b2dd411a9808754f62d436c4ca194b)
